{{About|the film|the car|Ford Torino|the manga and anime character|List of My Hero Academia characters#Other Heroes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Gran Torino | image = Gran Torino poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Clint Eastwood]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Clint Eastwood * [[Bill Gerber]] * [[Robert Lorenz]]}} | screenplay = [[Nick Schenk]] | story = {{Plainlist| * Dave Johannson * Nick Schenk}} | starring = Clint Eastwood<!-- per poster --> | music = {{Plainlist| * [[Kyle Eastwood]] * [[Michael Stevens (composer)|Michael Stevens]] * [[Jamie Cullum]]}} | cinematography = [[Tom Stern (cinematographer)|Tom Stern]] | editing = {{Plainlist| * [[Joel Cox]] * [[Gary D. Roach]]}} | studio = {{Plainlist| * Double Nickel Entertainment * [[Malpaso Productions]] * [[Village Roadshow Pictures]]}} | distributor = [[Warner Bros.]] | released = {{Film date|2008|12|12}} | runtime = 116 minutes<!--Theatrical runtime: 116:25--><ref>{{cite web | url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/gran-torino-2009-0 | title=''GRAN TORINO'' (15) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=December 17, 2008 | accessdate=April 6, 2015}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $25–33 million<ref name="foxnews1" /><ref name=numbers/> | gross = $270 million<ref name="BoxMojo" /> }}
'''''Gran Torino''''' is a 2008 American [[drama film]] directed and produced by [[Clint Eastwood]], who also starred in the film. The film co-stars [[Christopher Carley]], [[Bee Vang]] and [[Ahney Her]]. This was Eastwood's first starring role since 2004's ''[[Million Dollar Baby]]''. The film features a large [[Hmong American]] cast, as well as one of Eastwood's younger sons, [[Scott Eastwood|Scott]]. Eastwood's oldest son, [[Kyle Eastwood|Kyle]], provided the [[Film score|score]]. ''Gran Torino'' opened via a [[Limited release|limited theatrical release]] in [[North America]] on December 12, 2008, and later to a [[Wide release|worldwide release]] on January 9, 2009.<ref name="variety1" /> Set in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], it is the first mainstream American film to feature Hmong Americans. Many Lao Hmong war refugees resettled in the U.S. following the communist takeover of Laos in 1975.<ref name="YuenMixed">Yuen, Laura. "[http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2008/12/19/grantorino/ Hmong get a mixed debut in new Eastwood film]." ''[[Minnesota Public Radio]]''. December 18, 2008. Retrieved on March 18, 2012.</ref>
The story follows [[Walt Kowalski]], a recently widowed [[Korean War]] veteran alienated from his family and angry at the world. Walt's young neighbor, [[List of Gran Torino characters#Thao Vang Lor|Thao Vang Lor]], is pressured by his cousin into stealing Walt's prized 1972 [[Ford Gran Torino]] for his initiation into a gang. Walt thwarts the theft with his [[M1 Garand]] rifle and subsequently develops a relationship with the boy and his family.
''Gran Torino'' grossed nearly $270 million worldwide (making it Eastwood's second highest-grossing film to date).<ref name="BoxMojo" /> Within the Hmong community in the United States, the film received both praise and criticism.
==Plot== [[Walt Kowalski]] is a cantankerous, retired [[Polish American]] [[assembly line]] worker and [[Korean War]] veteran, who has recently been widowed after 50 years of marriage, causing him to be a [[lapsed Catholic]]. His [[Highland Park, Michigan|Highland Park]] neighborhood in the [[Detroit]] area of Michigan, formerly populated by working-class white families, is now dominated by poor Asian immigrants, and [[gang]] violence is commonplace. Adding to his isolation and detachment are his feelings towards his married sons and their families.
He rejects a suggestion from one of his sons to move to a retirement community (sensing that they want his home and possessions), and lives alone with his elderly dog, Daisy. A longtime cigarette smoker, Walt suffers from coughing fits, occasionally coughing up blood, but conceals this from his family. Roman Catholic priest Father Janovich tries to comfort him, but Walt disdains the young, inexperienced man. Eventually, Walt opens up to the priest, revealing that he is still haunted by memories of the war.
The [[Hmong people|Hmong]] Vang Lor family reside next door to Walt. Initially, he wants nothing to do with his new neighbors, particularly after he catches [[Thao Vang Lor|Thao]] attempting to steal his [[Ford Torino#1972.E2.80.931976: Gran Torino|1972 Ford Gran Torino]] as a coerced initiation into a Hmong gang run by Thao's cousin, Fong, whose nickname is "Spider". The gang is infuriated by Thao's failure and they attack him, but Walt confronts them with an [[M1 Garand]] rifle and chases them off, earning the respect of the Hmong community.
As penance, Thao's mother makes him work for Walt, who has him do [[Handyman|odd jobs]] around the neighborhood, and the two form a grudging mutual respect. Thao's sister Sue introduces Walt to Hmong culture and helps him bond with the Hmong community, who soon become more like family to Walt than his actual family and he, in turn, becomes a better man to them than he was to his own sons. Walt helps Thao get a job and gives him dating advice. Walt eventually visits a doctor regarding his coughing fits, where it's implied that he does not have long to live.
Spider's gang continues to pressure Thao, assaulting him on his way home from work. After he sees Thao's injuries, Walt visits the gang's house, where he attacks a gang member as a warning. In retaliation, the gang performs a [[drive-by shooting]] on the Vang Lor home, injuring Thao. They also beat up Sue, and Walt is upset by this. Father Janovich tells him that the gang raped her and she is safe at the hospital. There are no other witnesses; the community members, including the victims, refuse to assist the police to incriminate the gang members.
The next day, Thao seeks Walt's help to exact revenge, and Walt tells him to return later in the afternoon. In the meantime, Walt makes personal preparations: he buys a suit, gets a haircut, and makes a [[Confession (religion)|confession]] to Father Janovich, who had pressured him to make it at the behest of his late wife. When Thao returns, Walt takes him to the basement, gives him his [[Silver Star]] medal, then locks him in the basement and tells him of his haunting memory of having killed a surrendering enemy soldier. He keeps Thao locked in the basement, until the revenge is over, to make sure the boy will never be haunted by killing someone, with his life ahead of him.
That night, Walt goes to the gang members' house, where they draw their firearms on him. He loudly berates them and enumerates their crimes, drawing the attention of the neighbors. Putting a cigarette in his mouth, he asks for a light, then puts his hand in the pocket of his jacket and provocatively pulls it out as if he were holding a gun, causing the gang members to shoot and kill him. As he falls to the ground, his hand opens to reveal the [[Zippo]] cigarette lighter with the [[1st Cavalry Division (United States)|1st Cavalry]] insignia; he was unarmed. His plan had in fact been to provoke them into killing him in public. Sue, following Walt's directions, frees Thao, and they drive to the scene in Walt's Gran Torino. One of the police officers tells them that all gang members have been placed under arrest for the murder, and due to the number of witnesses, they all face a lengthy sentence in prison.
Walt's funeral mass is celebrated by Father Janovich and attended by his family and many of the Hmong community, many of whom are wearing traditional attire; their presence visibly puzzles Walt's family. Later, his last will and testament is read. To his family's surprise, Walt leaves them nothing. His house goes to the church and his cherished Gran Torino goes to Thao, with the condition that he does not modify the vehicle. Later, Thao is seen driving the car along [[Jefferson Avenue (Detroit)|Jefferson Avenue]] with Daisy.
==Cast== {{See also|List of Gran Torino characters}} {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Clint Eastwood]] as [[Walt Kowalski]] * [[Bee Vang]] as Thao Vang Lor, a young Hmong teenager * [[Ahney Her]] as Sue Lor, Thao's older sister * [[Christopher Carley]] as Father Janovich * [[Doua Moua]] as Fong "Spider," Thao's cousin and the main antagonist * Sonny Vue as Smokie, Spider's right-hand man * Elvis Thao as Hmong Gangbanger No. 1 * [[Brian Haley]] as Mitch Kowalski, Walt's older son * [[Brian Howe (actor)|Brian Howe]] as Steve Kowalski, Walt's younger son * [[Geraldine Hughes]] as Karen Kowalski, Mitch's wife * [[Dreama Walker]] as Ashley Kowalski, Mitch and Karen's daughter * Michael E. Kurowski as Josh Kowalski, Mitch and Karen's son * [[John Carroll Lynch]] as Martin, an Italian American barber friend of Walt's * Chee Thao as Grandma Vang Lor, the matriarch of Thao's family * Choua Kue as Youa, Thao's eventual girlfriend * [[Scott Eastwood]] as Trey, Sue's [[wigger]] date {{div col end}}
After holding casting calls in [[Fresno, California|Fresno]], [[California]], [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], and [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|Saint Paul]], [[Minnesota]], Eastwood selected ten Hmong lead actors and supporting actors. Of them, only one was not a first time actor.<ref name="set"/> Of the Hmong cast, five, including Bee Vang,<ref name="YuenMixed"/> one of the principal actors,<ref name="Sternberg">Sternberg, Laura. "[http://detroit.about.com/od/jobsbusiness/a/Gran_torino.htm Information About Clint Eastwood's "Gran Torino" and Hmong in Detroit]." ([https://www.webcitation.org/66GVM5eaF?url=http://detroit.about.com/od/jobsbusiness/a/Gran_torino.htm Archive]) ''[[About.com]]''. Retrieved on March 18, 2012.</ref> were from the state of [[Minnesota]].<ref name="YuenMixed"/> [[Ahney Her]] comes from [[Lansing, Michigan]]. The casting agency Pound & Mooney recruited thirty actors and over 500 extras. The firm recruited many Hmong actors from a Hmong soccer tournament in [[Macomb County, Michigan]].<ref name="Sternberg"/> Sandy Ci Moua, a Hmong actress based in the Twin Cities, assisted with the film's casting of Hmong actors.<ref>Lee, Gary Yia and Nicholas Tapp. ''Culture and Customs of the Hmong''. [[Greenwood Publishing Group]]. [[ABC-CLIO]], 2010. [https://books.google.com/books?id=RZEFgIhfdJEC&pg=PA79&dq=%22Sandy+Ci+Moua+is+another+longtime+actress%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=OkaKT8HrAorM9QSwhr21CQ&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Sandy%20Ci%20Moua%20is%20another%20longtime%20actress%22&f=false 79]. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] on April 14, 2012. {{ISBN|0-313-34526-0}}, 9780313345265.</ref>
==Production== ''Gran Torino'' was written by [[Nick Schenk]] and directed by Clint Eastwood.<ref name="set" /> It was produced by [[Village Roadshow Pictures]], Media Magik Entertainment and [[Malpaso Productions]] for film distributor [[Warner Bros.]] Eastwood co-produced with his Malpaso partners [[Robert Lorenz]] and [[Bill Gerber]].<ref name="variety2">{{cite news |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117982650.html |title=Eastwood to direct ''Gran Torino'' |last=Garrett |first=Diane |author2=Pamela McClintock |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=March 18, 2007 |accessdate=October 24, 2008}}</ref> Eastwood has stated he enjoyed the idea "that it dealt with prejudice, that it was about never being too old to learn".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Whittey|first1=Stephen|title=Clint Eastwood on 'Jersey Boys,' taking risks and a life well lived|url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2014/06/jersey_boys_clint_eastwood_director_four_seasons.html|website=NJ.com|accessdate=10 October 2015}}</ref>
[[Principal photography|Shooting]] began in July 2008.<ref name="grosse">{{cite news |title=Clint Eastwood begins shooting movie in Grosse Pointe Shores |work=[[The Detroit News]] |date=2008-07-15}}</ref> Hmong crew, production assistants, consultants, and extras were used.<ref name="set" /><ref name="schein">{{cite news |last=Schein |first=Louisa |title=Hmong Actors Making History: The Bad Guys Of Eastwood's Gran Torino |work=New America Media |url=http://news.newamericamedia.org/news/view_article.html?article_id=9c74f65fbd40944ddeba5271a1013bd0 |publisher=[[Pacific News Service]] |date=September 3, 2008 |accessdate=October 28, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080919160710/http://news.newamericamedia.org/news/view_article.html?article_id=9c74f65fbd40944ddeba5271a1013bd0 |archivedate=September 19, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The film was shot over five weeks. Joel Cox and Gary D. Roach, the editors, cut the film so it was under two hours long.<ref name="McCarthy">McCarthy, Todd. "[http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117939157?refcatid=31 Gran Torino]." ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''. Thursday December 4, 2008. Retrieved on March 17, 2012.</ref> The crew spent over $10 million while shooting the film in Detroit.<ref name="Sternberg"/>
In the early 1990s, Schenk became acquainted with the history and culture of the Hmong while working in a factory in Minnesota.<ref name="LongwellHmong1" /> He also learned how they had sided with the [[ARVN|South Vietnamese forces]] and its US allies during the [[Vietnam War]], only to wind up in [[refugee camps]], at the mercy of [[North Vietnam]]ese [[Communist]] forces, when US troops pulled out and the government forces were defeated.<ref name="LongwellHmong1" /> Years later, he was deciding how to develop a story involving a widowed Korean War veteran trying to handle the changes in his neighborhood when he decided to place a Hmong family next door and create a culture clash.<ref name="LongwellHmong1" /> He and Dave Johannson, Schenk's brother's roommate, created an outline for the story.<ref name="LongwellHmong1" /> According to Schenk, each night he used a pen and paper to write the script while in Grumpy's, a bar in northeastern Minneapolis, while not working at his day jobs. He recalled writing 25 pages within a single night in the bar. He recalled asking the bartender, who was his friend, questions about the story's progress.<ref name="GoldsteinRainey">Goldstein, Patrick and James Rainey. "[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/the_big_picture/2008/11/rookie-screenwr.html Rookie screenwriter finds the right mentor: Clint Eastwood]." ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''. November 26, 2008. Retrieved on March 22, 2012.</ref> Some industry insiders told Schenk that a film starring an elderly main character could not be produced, as the story could not be sold,<ref name="LongwellHmong1" /> especially with an elderly main character who used language suggesting that he held racist views.<ref name="GoldsteinRainey"/> Through a friend, Schenk sent the screenplay to Warner Bros. producer Bill Gerber.<ref name="LongwellHmong1" /> Eastwood was able to direct and star on the project as filming for ''[[Invictus (film)|Invictus]]'' was delayed to early 2009, leaving sufficient time for filming ''Gran Torino'' during the previous summer.<ref name="LongwellHmong1" /> Eastwood said that he had a "fun and challenging role, and it's an oddball story."<ref name="LongwellHmong1" />
According to Schenk, aside from changing Minneapolis references to Detroit references, the production headed by Eastwood "didn't change a single syllable" in the script.<ref name="YuenAlmost">Yuen, Laura. "[http://minnesota.publicradio.org/display/web/2009/01/08/nick_schenk/ 'Gran Torino' a movie made in Minnesota, almost]." ''[[Minnesota Public Radio]]''. January 9, 2009. Retrieved on May 14, 2012.</ref> Schenk added that the concept of the producers not making any substantial revisions to a submitted script "never happens."<ref name="Headlam"/> Eastwood said that he stopped making significant revisions after attempting to change the script of ''[[Unforgiven]]'' and later deciding to return to the original revision, believing that his changes were "emasculating" the product.<ref name="Headlam"/>
===Selection of Detroit for production and setting=== The original script was inspired by the [[Northeast, Minneapolis|Northeast]] community of [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]], but filmmakers chose to shoot in [[Michigan]], becoming one of the first productions to take advantage of the state's new law that provided lucrative incentive packages to film productions.<ref name="graham">{{cite news |last=Graham |first=Adam |title=Clint Eastwood attracts giddy gawkers |work=[[The Detroit News]] |date=2007-07-18}}</ref> [[Bill Huizenga]], a man from [[Zeeland, Michigan|Zeeland]], [[Michigan]] who once served in the [[Michigan House of Representatives]], helped write and coordinate the State of Michigan's incentive package to the film creators.<ref name=grp>{{cite news |first=Rachel|last=Recker|title=Gran Torino actress Ahney Her returns to Michigan for opening night |url=http://www.mlive.com/movies/index.ssf/2009/01/gran_torino_actress_ahney_her_1.html|work= [[The Grand Rapids Press]] |publisher= |date=2009-01-09 |accessdate=2009-01-11}}</ref> The film ultimately received a 42% [[tax credit]]. Bruce Headlam of ''[[The New York Times]]'' said "That helped make it easy for Warner Bros. to sign off on bankrolling the movie, something that hasn’t always been a given in the studio’s relationship with the director."<ref name="Headlam">Headlam, Bruce. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/14/movies/14head.html?pagewanted=all The Films Are for Him. Got That?]" ''[[The New York Times]]''. December 10, 2008. Retrieved on May 14, 2012.</ref>
Producer Robert Lorenz said that while the script was originally set in Minnesota, he chose Michigan as the actual setting as Kowalski is a retired car plant worker.<ref name="donn2">{{cite news |last=Donnelly |first=Francis |title=Culture shock, poverty plague Hmong in Michigan |url=http://www.detnews.com/2005/metro/0504/12/A01-147925.htm |work=[[The Detroit News]] |date=2005-04-12}}</ref> [[Metro Detroit]] was the point of origin of the [[Ford Motor Company]].<ref name="Headlam"/> Schenk said that sometimes the lines in the movie feel out of place with the Detroit setting; for instance a line about one of Walt's sons asks if Walt still knows a person who has season tickets for [[Minnesota Vikings]] games was changed to being about a person with [[Detroit Lions]] tickets. Schenk said "They don't sell out in Detroit. And so that bothered me. It seemed really untrue to me."<ref name="YuenAlmost"/>
===Shooting locations=== [[File:St. Ambrose Catholic Church - Grosse Pointe, Michigan.jpg|thumb|Saint Ambrose Roman Catholic Church in [[Grosse Pointe Park]] served as a shooting location]] Locations, all within [[Metro Detroit]], included [[Highland Park, Michigan|Highland Park]], [[Center Line, Michigan|Center Line]],<ref name="allard1">{{cite news|last=Allard |first=Maria |title=Clint Eastwood films scene for new movie in Highland Park, Center Line |url=http://www.candgnews.com/Homepage-Articles/2008/7-16-08/WF-MOVIE.asp |work=C & G News |publisher=C & G Publishing |date=2007-07-16 |accessdate=2007-12-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080721024628/http://www.candgnews.com/Homepage-Articles/2008/7-16-08/WF-MOVIE.asp |archivedate=July 21, 2008 }}</ref> [[Warren, Michigan|Warren]], [[Royal Oak, Michigan|Royal Oak]], and [[Grosse Pointe Park, Michigan|Grosse Pointe Park]] were used.<ref name="hall3">{{cite news |last=Hall |first=Christina |title=The film set next door: Lights... camera... Clint Eastwood! |work=[[Detroit Free Press]] |date=2007-07-15}}</ref> The house depicting Walt Kowalski's house is on<!--Do NOT specify a house number WITHOUT supplying a source saying so!--> Rhode Island Street in Highland Park. The Hmong gang house is located on Pilgrim Street in Highland Park. The house depicting the residence of one of Walt's sons is on Ballantyne Road in Grosse Pointe Shores. The church used in the film, Saint Ambrose Roman Catholic Church, is in Grosse Pointe Park. The hardware store, Pointe Hardware, is also in Grosse Pointe Park. VFW Post 6756, used as the location where Walt meets friends to drink alcohol, is in Center Line.<ref name="Sternberg"/>
[[File:WidgrenBarberShopMichigan.JPG|thumb|left|Widgren's Barber Shop in [[Royal Oak, Michigan|Royal Oak]] was another shooting location]] The barber shop, Widgren's Barber Shop, is along [[Roads and freeways in metropolitan Detroit|11 Mile Road]],<ref name="Sternberg"/> near Center Street, in Royal Oak. The shop, founded in 1938, in a space now occupied by another business, moved to its current location, west of its original location, in 1970. The film producers selected that shop out of 60 candidates in Metro Detroit. According to Frank Mills, the son-in-law of owner Ted Widgren, the producers selected it because they liked "the antique look inside."<ref name="Carroll">Carroll, Jeremy. "[http://www.candgnews.com/2008/7-16-08/RF-EASTWOOD Hollywood legend films scenes in Royal Oak barber shop]." ''[[C&G News]]''. July 16, 2008. Retrieved on March 18, 2012.</ref> Eastwood asked Widgren to act as an extra in the barber shop scene. In the area around the barbershop, vehicle traffic had to be stopped for three to five minutes at a time, so traffic in the area slowed down.<ref name="Carroll"/>
===Shooting and acting=== Of the entire cast, only Eastwood was an established actor; the Hmong actors had relatively little experience,<ref name="Baenen">Baenen, Jeff. "[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BTxJAAAAIBAJ&pg=2517,1335505 Teen makes acting debut after auditioning 'on a lark']." ''[[Associated Press]]'' at ''[[The Post and Courier]]''. Tuesday January 20, 2009. 2A. Retrieved from [[Google News]] (2 of 21) on March 17, 2012.</ref> and some were not proficient in English.<ref name="Headlam"/> Jeff Baenen said that Eastwood used a "low-key approach to directing."<ref name="Baenen"/> Eastwood said that "I’d give them little pointers along the way, Acting 101. And I move along at a rate that doesn’t give them too much of a chance to think."<ref name="Headlam"/> [[Bee Vang]] said that he originally felt fright, but was able to ease into the acting.<ref name="Baenen"/> Baenen said that Eastwood was a "patient teacher" of the first-time actors.<ref name="Baenen"/> According to Vang, Eastwood did not say "action" whenever filming a particular shoot began.<ref name="Baenen"/>
Vang said that he had studied the script as if it was a textbook. According to Vang, after the first film cut ended, Vang did not hear a response from Eastwood. When Vang asked if something was wrong, other people told Vang that if Eastwood did not make a comment, then his performance was satisfactory.<ref name="Battle">Battle, Roxane. "[http://www.minnpost.com/arts-arena/2009/02/aspiring-actors-or-moral-agents-hmong-panelists-look-back-their-roles-gran-torino Aspiring actors or moral agents: Hmong panelists look back at their roles in 'Gran Torino']." ''[[Minn Post]]''. February 23, 2009. Retrieved on March 17, 2012.</ref> Vang added that Eastwood encouraged ad-libbing with the Hmong actors.<ref name="Baenen"/> [[Ahney Her]] said that she liked the improvisation work, even when she was required to translate between the English and Hmong languages.<ref name="ScheinFamily">Schein, Louisa. "[http://news.newamericamedia.org/news/view_article.html?article_id=506b407281c5f9afd1a757cb9c3dca80 Hmong Actors Making History Part 2: Meet the Gran Torino Family] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110617082429/http://news.newamericamedia.org/news/view_article.html?article_id=506b407281c5f9afd1a757cb9c3dca80 |date=June 17, 2011 }}." ''[[Hmong Today]]'' at ''[[New America Media]]. October 4, 2008. Retrieved on March 17, 2012.</ref> When asked if the in-character racial slurs offended the actors in real life, Ahney<!--avoiding awkward "Her said" which sounds funny in English--> said that she did not feel offense. Vang said "I was called so many names that I can’t say here because of how vulgar they were. It disturbed me quite a lot, but at the end of the day it was just a script."<ref name="Battle"/>
Vang said in a 2011 program that Eastwood did not allow the Hmong actors to change their lines, despite what he said in the earlier interviews.<ref name="Reyes-Ortiz">Reyes-Ortiz, Kristy. "[http://thebottomline.as.ucsb.edu/2011/01/gran-torino-actor-reveals-behind-the-scenes-racism/ Gran Torino Actor Reveals Behind-the-Scenes Racism]." ([https://www.webcitation.org/66GTSuDWg?url=http://thebottomline.as.ucsb.edu/2011/01/gran-torino-actor-reveals-behind-the-scenes-racism Archive]) ''[[University of California Santa Barbara|The Bottom Line]]''. Associated Students, [[University of California Santa Barbara]]. January 25, 2011. Retrieved on March 17, 2012.</ref>
===Hmong people and culture during the production=== [[Nick Schenk]] said that he became friends with many Hmong coworkers while employed at a VHS factory in [[Bloomington, Minnesota|Bloomington]], [[Minnesota]]. In regards to Schenk's stories of his interactions with the Hmong people, Laura Yuen of ''[[Minnesota Public Radio]]'' said "That sense of humor and curiosity permeate the script, even though the ''Gran Torino'' trailers make the movie look like, by all measures, a drama."<ref name="YuenAlmost"/>
Eastwood wanted Hmong as cast members, so casting director [[Ellen Chenoweth]] enlisted Hmong organizations and set up calls in Detroit, Fresno and Saint Paul; Fresno and Saint Paul have the two largest Hmong communities in the United States, while Detroit also has an appreciable population of Hmong.<ref name="donn2"/> Chenoweth recruited [[Bee Vang]] in St. Paul and [[Ahney Her]] in Detroit.<ref name="LongwellHmong1" />
The screenplay was written entirely in [[English language|English]]. Therefore, the actors of ''Gran Torino'' improvised the [[Hmong language|Hmong]] used in the film. Louisa Schein, author of ''Hmong Actors Making History Part 2: Meet the Gran Torino Family'', said before the end of production that "some of the lines actors [[ad-libbed]] in Hmong on camera will be tricky to translate back for subtitles."<ref name="ScheinFamily"/> Screenwriter [[Nick Schenk]] had input from Hmong people when writing the script.<ref>Schein, Louisa. "[http://news.newamericamedia.org/news/view_article.html?article_id=9c74f65fbd40944ddeba5271a1013bd0 Hmong Actors Making History: The Bad Guys Of Eastwood's Gran Torino] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080919160710/http://news.newamericamedia.org/news/view_article.html?article_id=9c74f65fbd40944ddeba5271a1013bd0 |date=September 19, 2008 }}." ''[[Hmong Today]]'' at ''[[New America Media]]''. September 3, 2008. Retrieved on March 17, 2012.</ref> Dyane Hang Garvey served as a cultural consultant, giving advice on names, traditions, and translations.<ref name="YuenMixed"/>
Vang argued that the use of the Hmong people did not seem relevant to the overall plot. He said "there is no real reason for us to be Hmong in the script" and that even though [[Walt Kowalski]] had fought in Korea, he had still confused the Hmong with Koreans and other Asian ethnic groups.<ref name="Interview6">"''Gran Torino''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s Hmong Lead Bee Vang on Film, Race and Masculinity Conversations with Louisa Schein, Spring, 2010." p. 6.</ref> In a 2011 program Vang said that Hmong actors were treated unfairly on the set, and that Eastwood did not give tips on how to build the characters.<ref name="Reyes-Ortiz"/> Vang also said that other white cast members made Hmong actors feel excluded.<ref name="Reyes-Ortiz"/> Vang said that some important lines that the Hmong characters said in the Hmong language were not subtitled, so audiences developed a skewed perception of the Hmong people.<ref name="Reyes-Ortiz"/>
Roxane Battle of ''[[MinnPost]]'' said "Rutgers University professor Louisa Shein, an expert on Hmong studies, adeptly moderated the discussion and challenged the audience to view the young cast members for what they were: actors in a film, and not so much representatives of an entire culture."<ref name="Battle"/>
====Cultural accuracies and inaccuracies==== <!--ONLY list accuracies and inaccuracies identified in secondary sources and/or interview transcripts!!!!--> [[Bee Vang]], as paraphrased by Jeff Baenen of the ''[[Associated Press]]'', said that the film's portrayal of the Hmong is "generally accurate."<ref name="Baenen"/> Regarding the result, Vang said "[t]his film is not a documentary. We can't expect 101 percent correctness."<ref name="Baenen"/> During the filming, Hmong cast members addressed what they believed to be cultural inaccuracies that were being introduced. Cedric Lee,<ref name="Battle"/> a half-Hmong<ref>Walton, Michael. "[http://www2.metrotimes.com/editorial/story.asp?id=15361 French connection]." ''[[Metro Times]]''. September 15, 2010. Retrieved on May 12, 2012.</ref> who worked as a production assistant and a cultural consultant, said that "Some things were over-exaggerated for dramatic purposes. Whether it was our job or not, I still felt some responsibility to speak our mind and say something, but at the same time, the script was what it was. We didn’t make the final decision."<ref name="Battle"/> Vang said while many Hmong had objected to some elements, the producers selected the viewpoints of the cultural consultants which "had the most amenable take on the matter and would lend credence to whatever [[Stereotypes of East Asians in the Western world|Hollywood stereotypes]] the film wanted to convey."<ref name="Brauer">Brauer, David. "[http://www.minnpost.com/braublog/2011/04/hmong-american-actor-pans-kdwb-and-gran-torino-which-he-starred Hmong-American actor pans KDWB – and 'Gran Torino,' which he starred in]." ''[[MinnPost]]''. April 7, 2011. Retrieved on March 17, 2012.</ref> Vang further said that "this was a [[White American|white]] production, that our presence as actors did not amount to control of our images."<ref name="Brauer"/>
Louisa Schein and Va-Megn Thoj, authors of "''Gran Torino''’s Boys and Men with Guns: Hmong Perspectives," said "Perhaps the most commonly voiced Hmong objections to the film concern its myriad cultural inaccuracies, exaggerations and distortion."<ref name="Schein49">Schein and Thoj, 49.</ref> Schein also said that "[t]he [Hmong] actors struggle, too, with their culture being made into spectacle."<ref name="set"/> Even though a real Hmong shaman acts as a Hmong shaman in the film, Schein said that "his expertise was overridden by the screenplay and the filming, which distorted the ceremonial scenes by making them inaccurately exotic."<ref name="set"/> Vang said that the tea ceremonies depicted in the film were not correctly performed.<ref name="Reyes-Ortiz"/> Even though, in the film, Hmong characters feel offense when Walt touches a girl on the head, Schein said that in real life in Hmong culture it is okay to touch a person on the head.<ref name="Battle"/> In other segments of the film, the Hmong shaman touches a baby's head without any negative criticism. Schein adds that Spider touches [[Thao Vang Lor]]'s head "without consequence."<ref name="Schein49"/> Christine Wilson Owens, author of "Hmong Cultural Profile," said "Most traditional Hmong elders, especially men, do not want strangers to touch their heads, or those of their children, due to their religious beliefs and personal values."<ref name="HmongHead1"/>
Thao and [[Sue Lor]] wear Hmong clothing to [[Walt Kowalski]]'s funeral. Hmong do not ordinarily wear traditional Hmong clothing to funerals.<ref name="Battle"/> Grandma Lor spits a [[betel nut]] she had been chewing to show contempt for Walt Kowalski, even though the Hmong do not chew betel nuts.<ref>Schein and Thoj, 24.</ref> The Hmong shaman reads Walt's personal character, when in real life he would communicate with the spirit world. In the film the shaman himself does a sacrifice of a chicken in a manner that Schein and Thoj say is "in dramatic ceremonial fashion," when in real life an assistant would do this "perfunctorily."<ref name="Schein49"/> The authors said that the ''hu plis'' ceremony done in honor of the baby has an incorrect spatial layout, that the clothing and grooming of the Hmong gangs is not correct, and "the obsequious making of offerings on doorstep" are not accurate.<ref name="Schein49"/> While Thao himself cleans dishes, Schein and Thoj add that he would not do this alone because he is in a house with other female family members.<ref name="Schein49"/> Schein and Thoj also add that there is "inconsistent use of the two Hmong dialects within one family."<ref name="Schein49"/> They also argue that members of a Hmong clan would not show aggression towards a member of a fellow clan and that they would not rape a member of their own clan, like the gang in the film rapes Sue.<ref name="Schein49"/> Sharon Her, a Hmong writer from New York, argued that the film had "confusion of Asian customs" and that "Hmong people do not use favors as a method of atonement nor do they endlessly shower individuals with gifts out of gratitude."<ref name=HoffmanHer>Hoffman, Kevin. "[http://blogs.citypages.com/blotter/2009/01/gran_torino_is.php Gran Torino is racist and insensitive, says Hmong writer] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121215141038/http://blogs.citypages.com/blotter/2009/01/gran_torino_is.php |date=December 15, 2012 }}." ''[[Citypages]]''. Wednesday January 7, 2009. Retrieved on November 10, 2012.</ref>
In regard to the early script, Her said "An early draft of the script even had names misspelled and referenced [[Chinese surnames]], a sloppy mistake that was easily corrected[.]"<ref name=HoffmanHer/>
==Release==
===Theatrical run=== In the film's opening weekend of wide release in the US, it grossed $29.5 million; as of December 12 2008, has taken in $269,541,625 worldwide.<ref name="BoxMojo">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=main&id=grantorino.htm |title=Gran Torino (2008) |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date=2008-12-12|accessdate=2008-06-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Movies/02/01/box.office.ew/index.html?iref=mpstoryview |title=''Taken'' steals No. 1 slot at box office |last=Rich |first=Joshua |journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |publisher=CNN |date=2008-02-01 |accessdate=2009-02-02}}</ref>
===Home media=== The film was released on June 9, 2009, in the United States in both standard [[DVD]] format and [[Blu-ray disc|Blu-ray]].<ref name="IGN-dvd-release" /> The disc includes bonus materials and extra features.<ref name="IGN-dvd-release" /> A featurette is included and a documentary about the correlation of manhood and the automobile.<ref name="avhd-dvd-release" /> The Blu-ray version presents the film in 2.40:1 ratio format, a digital copy, and the audio in multiple languages.<ref name="avhd-dvd-release" /><ref name="dvdt" />
About 4 million DVD units have been sold as of 2012, generating $67.4 million in revenue. Another 332,000 Blu-ray discs were sold, for $4.9 million, bringing the total to $72.4 million in home video sales.<ref name=numbers>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2008/GTORN-DVD.php |title=Gran Torino – DVD Sales |publisher=The Numbers |accessdate=2018-08-20}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Critical reviews=== [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports that 80% of 224 surveyed critics gave the film positive write-ups; the average score is 7.1/10. The site's consensus states: "Though a minor entry in Eastwood's body of work, ''Gran Torino'' is nevertheless a humorous, touching, and intriguing old-school parable."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/gran_torino/ |title=Gran Torino Movie Reviews |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=IGN Entertainment |accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref> At ''[[Metacritic]]'', which assigns a [[weighted average]] score out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, the film has received an average score of 72 based on 34 reviews.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/grantorino |title=Gran Torino (2008): Reviews |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=CNET Networks |accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref>
After seeing the film, ''[[The New York Times]]'' described the [[requiem]] tone captured by the film, calling it as "a sleek, muscle car of a movie made in the USA, in that industrial graveyard called Detroit". [[Manohla Dargis]] compared Eastwood's presence on film to ''[[Dirty Harry]]'' and the ''[[Man with No Name]]'', stating: "Dirty Harry is back, in a way, in ''Gran Torino'', not as a character, but as a ghostly presence. He hovers in the film, in its themes and high-caliber imagery, and of course, most obviously, in Mr. Eastwood’s face. It is a monumental face now, so puckered and pleated that it no longer looks merely weathered, as it has for decades, but seems closer to petrified wood."<ref name="NYT"/> The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' also praised Eastwood's performance and credibility as an action hero at the age of 78. [[Kenneth Turan]] said of Eastwood's performance, "It is a film that is impossible to imagine without the actor in the title role. The notion of a 78-year-old action hero may sound like a contradiction in terms, but Eastwood brings it off, even if his toughness is as much verbal as physical. Even at 78, Eastwood can make 'Get off my lawn' sound as menacing as 'Make my day', and when he says 'I blow a hole in your face and sleep like a baby', he sounds as if he means it".<ref>{{cite web|last=Turan |first=Kenneth |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/reviews/la-et-torino12-2008dec12,0,2314630.story |title=Review: ''Gran Torino'': Clint Eastwood, at 78, shows he's still a formidable action figure |date=December 12, 2008 |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=December 16, 2008}}</ref> [[Roger Ebert]] wrote that the film is "about the belated flowering of a man's better nature. And it's about Americans of different races growing more open to one another in the new century."<ref>{{cite web|last=Ebert |first=Roger |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20081217/REVIEWS/812179989 |title=Review: ''Gran Torino'' |date=December 17, 2008 |publisher=[[Chicago Sun-Times]] |accessdate=February 25, 2009}}</ref> Sang Chi and Emily Moberg Robinson, editors of ''Voices of the Asian-American and Pacific Islander Experience: Volume 1'', said that within the mainstream media, the film received "criticial acclaim" "for its nuanced portrayal of [[Asian Americans]]."<ref name="ChiRobinson327">Chi, Sang and Emily Moberg Robinson (editors). ''Voices of the Asian American and Pacific Islander Experience: Volume 1''. [[ABC-CLIO]], Feb 28, 2012. p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=55GHYJlvf7YC&pg=PA329&lpg=PA329&dq=Thao+%22Asian+Johnny+Depp%22&source=bl&ots=VWb56KqkbC&sig=jTaNZOlyKSwGhcExuPHJTr4ivmQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=koVjT8joN42qsALYu9ScCw&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Thao%20%22Asian%20Johnny%20Depp%22&f=false 327]. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] on March 16, 2012. {{ISBN|1-59884-354-0}}, 9781598843545.</ref> Louisa Schein and Va-Megn Thoj, authors of "''Gran Torino''’s Boys and Men with Guns: Hmong Perspective," said that the mainstream critical response was "centered on Eastwood‘s character and viewed the film mainly as a vision of multicultural inclusion and understanding."<ref>Schein and Thoj, 1.</ref>
[[Mark Harris (journalist)|Mark Harris]], columnist for ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', described it as "fantasy pretending to be social commentary", and accused it of peddling "the delusion that even the bigot next door has something to teach us all about heroism and self-sacrifice", adding "no, he doesn't".<ref>Harris, Mark. "[http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20255144,00.html All Rags, No Riches]." ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. January 23, 2009. Retrieved on March 18, 2012.</ref> Conversely, Nicole Sperling, also of ''Entertainment Weekly'', perceived it in the exact opposite manner. She called it a drama with "the commercial hook of a genre film" and described it further as "a meditation on tolerance wrapped in the disguise of a movie with a gun-toting Clint Eastwood and a cool car".<ref>Sperling, Nicole. "[http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20283201,00.html Adult Dramas in Decline]." ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''. June 5, 2009. Retrieved on March 16, 2012.</ref> Chi and Robinson said that within the Asian-American community, some criticized "depictions of Hmong men" and "the archetypical white savior trope that permeated the film".<ref name="ChiRobinson327"/>
===Reception in relation to the Hmong=== [[Clint Eastwood]]'s decision to cast Hmong actors, including amateur actors, received a positive reception in Hmong communities.<ref name="OBrienSchein">O'Brien, Kathleen. "[http://www.nj.com/entertainment/tv/index.ssf/2009/01/rutgers_scholar_helps_eastwood.html Rutgers scholar sheds light on 'Gran Torino' ethnic stars]." ''[[The Star-Ledger]]''. Thursday January 15, 2009. Retrieved on March 16, 2012.</ref> Tou Ger Xiong, a Hmong storyteller and performance artist from the [[Minneapolis-St. Paul]] who had auditioned for a role in the film, said that he had respect for the film because the producers actually cast Hmong instead of asking other Asian-Americans to mimic Hmong.<ref name="YuenMixed"/> Xiong also argued "First things first, let's get our foot in the door. Complain later."<ref name="YuenMixed"/> Dyane Hang Garvey, who served as a cultural consultant for the film production, said that the film was not intended to be a documentary on the Hmong people and that it positively highlights, as paraphrased by Laura Yuen of ''[[Minnesota Public Radio]]'', "the close-knit nature of the Hmong community in Detroit".<ref name="YuenMixed"/> [[Doua Moua]], a Hmong actor in the film, said that he had no regrets in playing a gang member, because, in the words of Laura Yuen of ''[[Minnesota Public Radio]]'', "gangs consumed his brother's life while they were growing up in [[St. Paul, Minnesota|Saint Paul]]".<ref name="YuenMixed"/> Moua added that many first generation Hmong are affected by gangs and drift into gangs due to a lack of father figures.<ref name="YuenMixed"/>
Louisa Schein, a [[Rutgers University]] anthropologist who is an expert on the [[Hmong customs and culture|Hmong culture]], approved the concept of Hmong achieving visibility in the [[popular culture of the United States]], but believed that the film may be promoting out of date stereotypes of the Hmong. Schein said that her Hmong friends were "touched" by the film's portrayal of Hmong culture redeeming and reaching out to [[Walt Kowalski]].<ref name="OBrienSchein"/> [[Bee Vang]], one of the Hmong actors, said that he was satisfied with the outcome of the film.<ref>"[http://www.hmongtoday.com/page11502451.aspx Bee Vang Interview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100628200759/http://www.hmongtoday.com/page11502451.aspx |date=June 28, 2010 }}." ''[[Hmong Today]]''. – See the {{YouTube|Yu-rLmzC3q0|second embedded video}} (uploaded on January 18, 2009). 0:00–0:03: Interviewer: "Hey, this is Bee Vang here. What did you think of the movie?" 0:03–0:05: [[Bee Vang|Vang]]: "Um, I'm very happy with the outcome"</ref><!--This is actually important, because it seems as if he may believe the contrary from other sources about it-->
Schein further added that the film seemed to give little prominence to the history of the Hmong, and that only two male Hmong, Thao and a gang member, were given depth in the story. Schein said "I feel a lot of the plot about the Eastwood character is driven by the fact that he is a veteran. Yet there is no possibility for representing the fact that the Hmong were veterans too."<ref name="OBrienSchein"/> An individual established a blog, eastwoodmovie-hmong.com, documenting what the author believed to be cultural inaccuracies of the film's depiction of the Hmong.<ref name="set"/>
David Brauer of ''[[MinnPost]]'' said that some Hmong liked ''Gran Torino'' and that many believed that the film was offensive.<ref name="Brauer"/> Actor Bee Vang said "Hmong around the country were furious about its negative stereotypes and cultural distortions" and that they confronted him when he spoke at events.<ref name="Brauer"/> Vang added that he engaged in "explaining my obligation as an actor while also recognizing that, as a Hmong-American, I didn't feel that I could own the lines I was uttering."<ref name="Brauer"/> Brauer said that in an opinion editorial released in 2011, Vang "isn't kind to the Clint Eastwood film".<ref name="Brauer"/> Krissy Reyes-Ortiz of ''[[University of California Santa Barbara|The Bottom Line]]'' of the [[University of California Santa Barbara]] said, based on Vang's testimony in a 2011 program, that "Though many of the people who have seen the film may have gotten a sense of satisfaction and joy from seeing that Walt overcame his racism, the people who acted as the Hmong members in the movie did not" and that "They were offended by the traces of racism that were included in the movie and that they experienced themselves on set".<ref name="Reyes-Ortiz"/> Some Hmong on internet message boards had posted criticisms of the film.<ref name="YuenMixed"/>
Philip W. Chung of ''[[AsianWeek]]'' said that Eastwood, portraying a White man, was the "main weapon" of the film even though screenwriter [[Nick Schenk]] "does his best to portray Hmong culture and the main Hmong characters with both depth and cultural sensitivity".<ref name=ChungWhiteMan>Chung, Philip W. {{cite web|url=http://www.asianweek.com/2008/12/31/the-white-man-saves-the-day-again-clint-eastwood-in-gran-torino-2/ |title="The White Man Saves the Day Again?" |accessdate=2012-03-17 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212154857/http://www.asianweek.com/2008/12/31/the-white-man-saves-the-day-again-clint-eastwood-in-gran-torino-2/ |archivedate=February 12, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} ''[[AsianWeek]]''. December 31, 2008. Retrieved on March 17, 2012.</ref> Chung argued that "''Gran Torino'' might have been another "“white man saves the day” story" but that "What Eastwood has really created is not a story about the white man saving the minority (though it can be read on that level and I’m sure some will) but a critical examination of an iconic brand of white macho maleness that he played a significant part in creating."<ref name=ChungWhiteMan/>
===Awards and nominations=== ''Gran Torino'' was recognized by the [[American Film Institute]] as one of the Ten Best Films of 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/tvevents/afiawards08/default.aspx |title=AFI Awards 2008 |work=afi.com |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |accessdate=December 16, 2008}}</ref> Clint Eastwood's performance has also garnered recognition. He won an award for Best Actor from the [[National Board of Review]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbrmp.org/awards/ |title=Awards for 2008 |work=nbrmp.org |publisher=[[National Board of Review]] |accessdate=December 16, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612165922/http://nbrmp.org/awards/ |archivedate=June 12, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> he was nominated for the [[Broadcast Film Critics Association]] (Critics' Choice Awards) and by the [[Chicago Film Critics Association Awards]] for Best Actor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bfca.org/ccawards/2008.php |title=The 14th Critics' Choice Awards Nominees |work=bfca.org |publisher=[[Broadcast Film Critics Association]] |accessdate=December 16, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4dHIvuj?url=http://www.bfca.org/ccawards/2008.php |archivedate=November 7, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/movies/391405_movieawards10.html |title=L.A., D.C. critics announce 2008 film awards |work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] |date=December 9, 2008 |accessdate=December 16, 2008}}</ref> An original song from the film, "Gran Torino", was nominated for the [[Golden Globe Awards]] for Best Original Song. The music is [[Jamie Cullum]], [[Kyle Eastwood]], and [[Michael Stevens (composer)|Michael Stevens]], with Cullum penning the lyrics, although Eastwood composed and performed the title track to the film.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goldenglobes.org/news/id/104 |title=Golden Globe Awards nominations for the year ended December 31, 2008 |work=goldenglobes.org |publisher=[[Hollywood Foreign Press Association]] |accessdate=December 16, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5u4dJX3el?url=http://www.goldenglobes.org/news/id/104 |archivedate=November 7, 2010 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The [[Art Directors Guild]] nominated ''Gran Torino'' in the contemporary film category.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/awardcentral_article/VR1117998295.html?nav=news&categoryid=1983&cs=1 |title=Art Directors Guild unveils nominees ''Button'', ''Doubt'', ''Torino'' among contenders |first=Justin |last=Kroll |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] |date=2009-01-09 |accessdate=2009-01-09}}</ref>
The film, however, was ignored by the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] at the [[81st Academy Awards]] when it was not nominated for a single Oscar, which led to heated criticism from many who felt that the Academy had also deliberately snubbed ''[[Revolutionary Road (film)|Revolutionary Road]]'', ''[[The Dark Knight (film)|The Dark Knight]]'', ''[[WALL-E]]'' and ''[[Changeling (film)|Changeling]]'' (which Eastwood also directed) from the five major categories.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lemire |first=Christy |title=Oscar nomination surprises and snubs |url=http://www.masslive.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2009/01/oscar_nomination_surprises_and.html |agency=Associated Press |date=2009-01-22 |accessdate=2009-02-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kreps |first=Daniel |title=Oscars Snub Springsteen, Celebrate "Slumdog" As Nominations Are Announced |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2009/01/22/oscars-snub-springsteen-celebrate-slumdog-as-nominations-are-announced/ |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=2009-01-22 |accessdate=2009-02-09}}</ref>
In 2010, the film was named [[César Award for Best Foreign Film|Best Foreign Film]] at the [[César Award]]s in [[France]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/8542601.stm |title=Prison drama A Prophet sweeps French Oscars|date= March 1, 2010 |work= BBC News|accessdate=28 April 2010}}</ref>

'''Gross out''' describes a [[art movement|movement]] in art (often comic), which aims to shock<ref>{{cite book|last=Eyman|first=Louis Giannetti, Scott|title=Flashback : a brief history of USA|year=2010|publisher=Pearson Education/Allyn & Bacon|location=Boston, MA|isbn=0-205-69590-6|pages=379|edition=6th}}</ref> and disgust the [[audience]] with controversial material such as [[toilet humour]], [[nudity]], or any sexual topic.
== Cinema ==
===Features=== Gross-out is a [[genre|subgenre]] of comedy movies in which the makers employ humor that is willfully "tasteless"<ref>{{cite book|last=Pryor]|first=Joe Garner ; foreword by Richard|title=Made you laugh! : the funniest moments in radio, television, stand-up, and movie comedy|year=2004|publisher=Andrews McMeel Pub.|location=Kansas City|isbn=0-7407-4695-2|pages=171}}</ref> or even downright disgusting. It usually involves gratuitous nudity,<ref>{{cite book|last=Capsuto|first=Steven|title=Alternate channels : the uncensored story of gay and lesbian images on radio and television|year=2000|publisher=Ballantine Books|location=New York, NY|isbn=0-345-41243-5|pages=250|edition=1.}}</ref> unrealistic aggressiveness towards property or [[Schadenfreude]]. The movies are generally aimed at a younger audience aged between 18 and 24.<ref>{{cite book|last=King|first=Geoff|title=Film comedy|year=2002|publisher=Wallflower|location=London [u.a.]|isbn=1-903364-35-3|pages=73|edition=repr.}}</ref> One boon of this genre is that it provides an inexpensive way to make a movie "edgy" and to generate media attention for it.
===History=== In the United States, following the abolition of the film industry's censorious [[Production Code]] and its replacement with the [[MPAA film rating system]] in the late 1960s, some filmmakers began to experiment with subversive<ref name= "Mitchell03">{{cite news | last = Mitchell | first = Elvis | authorlink = Elvis Mitchell | title = Revisiting Faber College (Toga, Toga, Toga!) | work = [[The New York Times]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date=25 August 2003 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2003/08/25/movies/critic-s-notebook-revisiting-faber-college-toga-toga-toga.html | accessdate = 2011-01-28 }}</ref> film comedies, which explicitly dealt with taboo subjects such as sex and other bodily functions. Noteworthy examples include 1972's ''[[Pink Flamingos]]'' (in which the central character eats dog excrement) and other films by [[John Waters (filmmaker)|John Waters]], and 1974's sketch comedy film ''[[The Groove Tube]]''. As these films emerged from the [[counterculture]] movement and gained a measure of audience success,<ref name="Mitchell03"/> they inspired more mainstream films to follow their example. However, long before the Production Code, early silent comedy film makers produced and attempted several 'gross-out' pictures to the disdain of early film reviewers. One such example is the [[lost film|lost]] ''[[Nell's Eugenic Wedding]]'' starring [[Fay Tincher]] and [[Tod Browning]].
The label "gross-out movie" was first applied by the mainstream media to [[1978 in film|1978]]'s ''[[National Lampoon (magazine)|National Lampoon]]'s [[Animal House]]'',<ref>{{cite book|last=Bernheimer|first=Kathryn|title=The 50 funniest movies of all time : a critic's ranking|year=1999|publisher=Carol Pub. Group|location=Secaucus, N.J.|isbn=0-8065-2091-4|pages=109–111}}</ref> a comedy about the [[Fraternities and sororities|fraternity]] experience at [[Higher education in the United States|US colleges]].<ref name="Mitchell03"/> Its humor included not only explicit use of bodily functions (like projectile vomiting), but also references to topical political matters like [[Kent State shootings]], [[Richard Nixon]], the [[Vietnam war]], and the [[Civil rights movement#Civil rights movement in the United States|civil rights movement]].<ref name= "Peterson">{{cite news | last = Peterson | first = Molly | title = ''National Lampoon's Animal House'' | work = [[National Public Radio]] | date = July 29, 2002 | url = https://www.npr.org/programs/morning/features/patc/animalhouse/ | accessdate = 2010-02-01 }}</ref> It was a great [[box office]] success despite its limited production costs and thus started an industry trend.<ref name="Mitchell03"/> Since then, gross-out films increased in number, and became almost the norm for American comedy films. Some films of this genre could be aimed at teen audiences (such as ''[[Superbad (film)|Superbad]]'', ''[[Porky's]]'', ''[[American Pie (series)|American Pie]]'' or ''[[Eurotrip]]''), while others are targeted at somewhat more mature audiences (such as ''[[There's Something About Mary]]'', ''[[The Hangover (film)|The Hangover]]'' or ''[[Wedding Crashers]]'').
== Television == {{advert|date=June 2012}}
''The Tom Green Show and [[Jackass (TV series)|Jackass]]'' and its UK cousin, ''[[Dirty Sanchez (television series)|Dirty Sanchez]]'', were the pioneers of "gross out television". The shows featured dangerous [[stunts]], [[nudity]], [[profanity]], and action new to the television platform. Both series were featured on [[MTV]], and progressed to feature-length movies. ''[[Beavis and Butt-Head]]'', ''[[The Ren & Stimpy Show]]'', [[Rugrats]], [[Rocko's Modern Life]], [[Aaahh!!! Real Monsters]], and ''[[Animaniacs]]'' transferred the gross-out television genre to the medium of small screen [[animation]] largely in the early 1990s. Today this continues with such shows as ''[[South Park]]'', ''[[Family Guy]]'', ''[[The Simpsons]]'', ''[[Futurama]]'', ''[[Rick and Morty]]'', [[Regular Show]], [[American Dad!]] and ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]''.
== Theater ==
Gross-out [[theater]] is increasingly practiced on stage, particularly in the [[Edinburgh Festival]]. However, it is also displayed in the larger and more adventurous [[United Kingdom|British]] theaters.
The prime examples of the above are the stage version of the contemporary drama ''[[Trainspotting (novel)#Stage adaptation|Trainspotting]]'' by bestselling playwright and author [[Irvine Welsh]]; the controversial New York musical ''[[Urinetown]]'' by Kotis and Hollmann; the outrageous [[anarchistic]] schlockomedy (shock horror comedy) musical about a Manchester jobcentre ''Restart'' by Komedy Kollective;<ref>[http://www.komedykollective.com komedykollective.com]</ref> and performances by another United Kingdom-based act, Forced Entertainment, who devised the [[iconic]] theatrical [[gorefest]] ''Bloody Mess''.
== Art ==
Controversial American cartoonist and vaudeville performer [[Basil Wolverton]] invented his trademark "[[spaghetti]] and [[meatball]]s" style of artwork.
Various artists helped create a flourishing gross-out art scene, which began mainly in the 1990s, the most famous of which were [[Damien Hirst]], known for encasing mutilated, rotting [[cattle]] in [[formaldehyde]], and making art of [[endangered]] [[Marine (ocean)|marine]] [[species]] such as [[shark]]s in formaldehyde tanks, and [[Tracey Emin]], whose [[Art exhibition|exhibit]] of an unmade [[bed]] featured used [[tampons]], [[condoms]] and blood-stained [[underwear]].
== Music ==
Gross out themes are common in popular music genres, such as [[Hip hop music|hip hop]] and [[hard rock]], where shock value helps create marketable notoriety. Bands include [[Blink-182]] famous for including [[breast]] and [[fart]] jokes in their songs, while bands such as [[Cannibal Corpse]] and [[Agoraphobic Nosebleed]] write extremely revolting lyrics designed to induce nausea and shock the music world.
Probably the biggest gross-out shock to the music world was the act of [[GG Allin]]. Allin was infamous for his transgressive music act, which included eating excrement, mutilating himself and attacking audience members.
Sometimes the line between truth and [[urban myth]] is blurred by the [[sensationalist]] sections of the media. For example, [[Frank Zappa]] never ate steaming excrement live on-stage, and the famed incident involving [[Ozzy Osbourne]] biting a head off of a bat was actually unintentional (he thought the bat was a prop).
Similar themes are also sometimes conveyed in music videos, the aptly named Gross Out, a [[Single (music)|single]] from [[indie (music)|indie]]/[[garage rock]] band, [[The Vines (band)|The Vines]].

[[Combat Action Ribbon]] |relations = |laterwork = |signature = |website = }} '''Harlon Henry Block''' (November 6, 1924 – March 1, 1945) was a [[United States Marine Corps]] corporal who was killed in action during the [[Battle of Iwo Jima]] in [[World War II]]. Born in [[Yorktown, Texas]], Block joined the Marine Corps with seven high school classmates in February 1943, and subsequently participated in combat on [[Bougainville campaign (1943-45)|Bougainville]] and Iwo Jima. He is best known for being one of the six flag-raisers who helped raise the second [[Flag of the United States|U.S. flag]] atop Mount Suribachi on February 23, 1945, as shown in the iconic photograph ''[[Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima]]''. The [[Marine Corps War Memorial]] located in Arlington, Virginia, which was modeled after the flag-raising photograph, depicts bronze statues of each of the six Marine flag-raisers. == Early life == Block was born in [[Yorktown, Texas]], the third of six children to Edward Frederick Block and Ada Belle Brantley, a [[Seventh-day Adventist Church|Seventh day-Adventist]] family.{{cite web |url=http://www.marines.mil/unit/mcbhawaii/Pages/2005/Famed%20Iwo%20Jima%20flag%20raisers%20gone%20but%20not%20forgotten.aspx |title=Famed Iwo Jima flag raisers gone but not forgotten |publisher=Marines.mil |date= |accessdate=2012-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007080257/http://www.marines.mil/unit/mcbhawaii/Pages/2005/Famed%20Iwo%20Jima%20flag%20raisers%20gone%20but%20not%20forgotten.aspx |archivedate=2012-10-07 |df= }} The Block children were: Edward, Jr., Maurine, Harlon, Larry, Corky, and Melford.Bradley, p. 31. Edward Frederick Block was a [[World War I]] veteran and supported his family by working as a dairy farmer.''[[Flags of Our Fathers]]'' by [[James Bradley (author)|James Bradley]], p. 29. In hopes of improving the family, the Block family relocated to [[Weslaco, Texas]], a city located in the [[Rio Grande Valley]]. His father became a dairy farmer, and the children attended a Seventh-day Adventist private school. Harlon Block was expelled in his freshman year when he refused to tell the principal which student had vandalized the school. Block then transferred to [[Weslaco High School]] and was remembered as an outgoing student with many friends. A natural athlete, Block led the Weslaco Panther Football Team to the Conference Championship. He was honored as "All South Texas End". Block and seven of his high school friends decided on joining the Marine Corps before they graduated and the school held a special early graduation ceremony for them in January 1943.Hendricks, Mark (7/26/2001), ''Iwo Jima: In Memory Of A Friend'', 7/26/2001 [http://www.dianahendricks.com/clips--essays--mark/in-memory-of-a-friend] Retrieved January 10, 2015[https://www.adventistreview.org/meet-harlan-block,-the-seventh-day-adventist-who-helped-raise-the-u.s.-flag-on-iwo-jima Meet Harlan Block, the Seventh-day Adventist Who Helped Raise the U.S. Flag on Iwo Jima] Retrieved October 12, 2018 == U.S. Marine Corps == {{Seventh-day Adventism}} === World War II === Block and seven of his high school football teammates enlisted together in the Marine Corps through the [[Selective Service System]] at [[San Antonio]] on February 18, 1943 and were sent to recruit training at the [[MCRD San Diego|Marine Corps Recruit Depot]] in [[San Diego]]. On April 14, Block began [[parachute]] training at the Marine Parachute Training School in San Diego, and on May 22, he qualified as a [[Paramarine]] and was promoted to [[private first class]]. He was sent to the [[Pacific Theater of World War II|Pacific Theater]]. He arrived at [[New Caledonia]] on November 15, where he served as a member of Headquarters and Service Company, [[1st Marine Parachute Regiment]], [[I Marine Amphibious Corps]]. On December 21, he landed on [[Bougainville Island|Bougainville]]. On December 22, 1st Parachute Battalion, Weapons Company and a Headquarters and Service platoon attached to the 2nd Marine Raider Regiment, relieved the [[1st Battalion, 3rd Marines]] in the vicinity of Eagle Creek on Bougainville. Block returned to San Diego with his unit on February 14. On February 29, the parachutists disbanded and Block joined the Second Platoon, E Company, [[2nd Battalion, 28th Marine Regiment]], [[5th Marine Division]] at [[Marine Corps Base Camp Pendleton|Camp Pendleton, California]] on March 1. He was promoted to [[corporal]] on October 27, 1944. ==== Flag raising(s) on Mount Suribachi ==== [[File:Iwo Jima Suribachi DN-SD-03-11845.JPEG|thumb|right|Mount Suribachi on Iwo Jima]] [[File:Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima (color).ogg|thumb|'''Block''' (holding flagstaff with back facing camera). A portion of the color film shot by Sgt. [[Bill Genaust]], USMC, excerpted from the 1945 "Carriers Hit Tokyo" newsreel]] On February 19, 1945, Block landed with the Second Battalion, 28th Marines who were nearest to Mount Suribachi at the southern end of Iwo Jima which was the battalion's objective, and fought in the battle for the capture of the island. On February 23, a 40-man patrol from mostly Third Platoon, Easy Company, was sent up Mount Suribachi to seize and occupy the crest and raise an American flag to signal that the mountaintop was captured. The patrol led by First Lieutenant [[Harold G. Schrier|Harold Schrier]] who carried the battalion's flag, left 8 AM and soon made it to the top of Mount Suribachi. The flag was raised by Lt. Schrier, Platoon Sergeant [[Ernest Ivy Thomas, Jr.|Ernest Thomas]], and Sergeant [[Henry Oliver Hansen|Henry Hansen]].[http://ruralfloridaliving.blogspot.com/2012/07/famous-floridian-friday-ernest-ivy.html] Rural Florida Living. Thomas was interviewed by CBS radio broadcaster Dan Pryor on February 25, 1945, aboard the [[USS Eldorado (AGC-11)]]: "''Three of us actually raised the flag''". After a brief firefight with Japanese soldiers who were hiding in caves after the flag was raised, the summit was secured. It was determined that the flag was too small to be seen on the north side of Mount Suribachi (where most of the Japanese were located and heavier fighting would occur), so another, larger flag was called for. At around noon or so, Marine Sgt. [[Michael Strank]] was ordered to take three of his squad members in Second Platoon up to the top of Suribachi with supplies and raise a replacement flag. He then chose Cpl. Block (assistant squad leader), Pfc. [[Ira Hayes]], and Pfc. [[Franklin Sousley]] to go with him up the mountain. Pfc. [[Rene Gagnon]], the Easy Company runner (messenger), was ordered to take the flag up and return with the first flag. Once on top, Strank told Hayes and Sousley to find a pipe to be used for a flagpole to tie the flag on. The flag was attached to a Japanese steel pipe they found, and as the four Marines were about to raise the flagstaff, Strank called for help from Gagnon and Pfc. [[Harold Schultz]] (Navy corpsman [[John Bradley (United States Navy)|John Bradley]] was incorrectly identified as a flag-raiser until June 23, 2016)[http://www.marines.mil/News/News-Display/Article/810457/usmc-statement-on-iwo-jima-flagraisers/ USMC Statement on Marine Corps Flag Raisers], Office of U.S. Marine Corps Communication, 23 June 2016 The six Marines then raised the replacement flag together as the first flag and flagstaff was lowered under Lt. Schrier's command. The second raising was immortalized forever by the black and white photo of the flag raising by [[Joe Rosenthal]] of the [[Associated Press]]. This flag-raising was also filmed in color by Sergeant [[Bill Genaust]] who was [[killed in action]] on March 4. Strank was killed in action on March 1, and Sousley on March 21, five days before the battle ended on March 26. ==== Death ==== According to the book ''[[Flags of Our Fathers]]'' by [[James Bradley (author)|James Bradley]] (son of Navy corpsman John Bradley), Block then assumed command of Strank's squad in Second Platoon after Strank was killed on March 1, and later the same day Block was mortally wounded by an enemy [[mortar (weapon)|mortar]] round explosion while leading the squad during an attack toward Nishi Ridge. Block's last words were, "They killed me!".{{cite book|last1=Bradley|first1=James|title=Flags of Our Fathers|date=May 2000|publisher=Bantam Books|location=New York|isbn=0-553589-34-2|pages=232–233}} However, Ralph Griffiths, a member of the same platoon as Block, claimed that Strank and Block were killed instantly by the same shell which wounded him on March 1.[https://taishawalker.wordpress.com/2012/11/12/iwo-jima-survivor-recalls-the-bloody-war/][http://listen.sdpb.org/post/marine-veterans-recall-iwo-jima#stream/0][http://www.vindy.com/news/2009/nov/14/veteran-of-easy-company-recalls-rigors-of-iwo-jima/?print] Block was originally buried in the 5th Marine Division Cemetery on Iwo Jima in 1945. A service was held there on March 26 which included Hayes and other members of Easy Company. In January 1949, Block's remains was re-interred in Weslaco, Texas. In 1995, his body was moved to a burial place at the [[Marine Military Academy]] near its Iwo Jima monument in [[Harlingen, Texas]].{{cite web|title=Block, Harlon Henry|url=https://tshaonline.org/handbook/online/articles/fbl52|website=The Handbook of Texas Online|publisher=Texas State Historical Association|accessdate=28 October 2015}}{{Find a Grave|18154|accessdate=September 22, 2010}} == Flag raising controversy == [[File:Raising the Flag outline.svg|thumb|right|A photo to show the identities of the six second flag-raisers on Mt. Suribachi]] A controversy arose as to the identity of the person shown at the right end and bottom of the flagstaff in the famous photograph of the second flag-raising on Mount Suribachi. When Block's mother first viewed Rosenthal's iconic photograph of the second flag-raising in the Weslaco newspaper on February 25, 1945, just two days after the photo was taken, she immediately exclaimed, "That's Harlon", pointing to the flag-raiser on the far right. She never wavered in her belief that it was Harlon in the photo, insisting, "I know my boy." On March 27, 1945, the 28th Marines departed Iwo Jima for Hawaii. On March 30, President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt|Franklin Roosevelt]] ordered the Marine Corps to send the flag-raisers in Rosenthal's photograph to Washington, D.C. where it was determined that Hansen was in the photograph. On April 7, [[Rene Gagnon]] (Easy Company's runner (messenger)), mistakenly identified the person in the photograph as Sergeant [[Henry O. Hansen|Hank Hansen]] of [[Boston]] (Hansen was a member of Third Platoon of Company E, who had participated in the first flag-raising on Mount Suribachi earlier that morning).[http://ruralfloridaliving.blogspot.com/2012/07/famous-floridian-friday-ernest-ivy.html] Rural Florida Living. CBS Radio interview by Dan Pryor with flag raiser Ernest "Boots" Thomas on February 25, 1945 aboard the [[USS Eldorado (AGC-11)]]: "''Three of us actually raised the flag''" On April 8, the Marine Corps released publicly the names of the six flag-raisers in the photograph which were identified by Gagnon (he also incorrectly identified Bradley in the photograph). When Navy corpsman John Bradley (Third Platoon corpsman, Easy Company, who was involved with the first flag-raising on Suribachi) arrived in Washington, D.C. a few days later, Bradley (he incorrectly identified himself in the photograph) concurred with Gagnon that Hansen was in the photograph. However, on April 19, when Ira Hayes (Second Platoon) arrived in Washington, D.C., he told the lieutenant colonel interviewing him (also interviewed Gagnon and Bradley) about who the flag-raisers were, that an "error" was made, Block (Second Platoon) and not Hansen was at the base of the flagstaff in the photo. Hayes (who incorrectly identified Bradley in the photograph) was then told the six names were already released and since Block and Hansen were both deceased, to not say a word about it again[[James Bradley (author)|Bradley, James]]. ''[[Flags of Our Fathers]]''. p. 417.(the lt. colonel later claimed Hayes never mentioned Block's name to him). In 1946, after Hayes was honorably discharged from the Marine Corps (December 1945), he visited Mr. Block at his home and told him Harlon was in the photograph. Mrs. Block then persuaded Mr. Block to write their congressman about the matter which he did in September, and the Marine Corps replied that an investigation would be held by them into the identities of the second flag-raisers in the Rosenthal photograph. During the following investigation, Hayes's written statements and letter to Mrs. Block in September 1945, were instrumental in proving Harlon Block was in the famous photograph and Hansen was not (Hayes, and Hansen who wore parachutist boots on Suribachi... were former [[Paramarines]]). Gagnon and Bradley who said it was Hansen, agreed that "it could be Block" after learning why Hayes said it was Block. The investigation which began in December and concluded in January 1947, found that it was indeed Block and not Hansen in the picture, and that no blame was to be placed on anyone in this matter. == Marine Corps War Memorial== [[File:USMC War Memorial Night.jpg|thumb|right|The [[USMC War Memorial|U.S. Marine Corps War Memorial]] in [[Arlington, Virginia|Arlington]], [[Virginia]]]] The [[Marine Corps War Memorial]] (also known as the Iwo Jima Memorial) in Arlington, Virginia which was inspired by Rosenthal's photograph of the second flag raising on Mount Suribachi was dedicated on November 10, 1954.[http://www.barracks.marines.mil/History/MarineCorpsWarMemorial.aspx The Marine Corps War Memorial] Marine Barracks Washington, D.C. Block is depicted as the first bronze statue at the bottom of the flagstaff with the 32 foot (9.8 m) bronze statues of the other five flag-raisers on the monument (as of June 23, 2016, [[Franklin Sousley]] is depicted as the third bronze statue from the bottom of the flagstaff and [[Harold Schultz]] is depicted as the fifth statue from the bottom of the flagstaff). [[President of the United States|President]] [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] sat upfront with [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Richard Nixon]], [[United States Deputy Secretary of Defense|Deputy Secretary of Defense]] [[Robert B. Anderson|Robert Anderson]], and General [[Lemuel C. Shepherd]], the 20th [[Commandant of the Marine Corps|Commandant]] of the Marine Corps during the dedication ceremony. Two of the three surviving flag-raisers depicted on the monument, [[Ira Hayes]] and [[Rene Gagnon]], were seated together with [[John Bradley (United States Navy)|John Bradley]] (he was incorrectly identified as a surviving flag-raiser) in the front rows of seats along with relatives of those who were killed in action on the island.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vgwrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jZoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4987%2C3731941 |newspaper=Reading Eagle|location=Pennsylvania|agency=Associated Press|title=Memorial honoring Marines dedicated |date=November 10, 1954|page=1}} Speeches were given by Richard Nixon, Robert Anderson who dedicated the memorial, and General Shepherd who presented the memorial to the American people.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cPNXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mfYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5563%2C2418577 |newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle |location=Washington |agency=Associated Press |title=Marine monument seen as symbol of hopes, dreams |date=November 10, 1954 |page=2}} Inscribed on the memorial are the following words: :In Honor And Memory Of The Men of The United States Marine Corps Who Have Given Their Lives To Their Country Since 10 November 1775 == Military awards == Block's military decorations and awards include:

|[[Presidential Unit Citation (United States)|Navy Presidential Unit Citation]] |- |[[American Campaign Medal]] |[[Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal]] with three [[Service star|{{frac|3|16}}" bronze stars]] |[[World War II Victory Medal]] |- |}

In the movie, Block is portrayed by [[Americans|American]] actor [[Benjamin Walker (actor)|Benjamin Walker]]. His parents are portrayed by Christopher Curry and [[Judith Ivey]]. The film is based on the 2000 [[Flags of Our Fathers|book of the same title]]. == Public honors == *[[Marine Corps War Memorial]] * Harlon Block exhibit, Weslaco Museum, Weslaco, Texas *Harlon Block Memorial (Texas National Guard Armory), Weslaco, Texas * Harlon Block Sports Complex (Park), Weslaco, Texas == See also == {{Portal|World War II|United States Marine Corps|Biography|Seventh-day Adventist Church|Christianity}} *[[Flags of Our Fathers]] *[[Raising the Flag on Iwo Jima]] *[[Shadow of Suribachi: Raising The Flags on Iwo Jima]] *[[Meliton Kantaria]] - Soviet flag raiser over the [[Reichstag (building)|Reichstag]] in [[Berlin]], 1945. *[[M.A. Yegorov|Mikhail Yegorov]] - Soviet flag raiser over the [[Reichstag (building)|Reichstag]] in [[Berlin]], 1945. {{Commons category|Harlon H. '''Headspace technology''' is a technique developed in the 1980s to elucidate the odor compounds present in the air surrounding various objects. Usually the objects of interest are odoriferous objects such as plants, flowers and foods.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Omar|first=Jone|last2=Olivares|first2=Maitane|last3=Alonso|first3=Ibone|last4=Vallejo|first4=Asier|last5=Aizpurua-Olaizola|first5=Oier|last6=Etxebarria|first6=Nestor|date=2016-04-01|title=Quantitative Analysis of Bioactive Compounds from Aromatic Plants by Means of Dynamic Headspace Extraction and Multiple Headspace Extraction-Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1750-3841.13257/abstract|journal=Journal of Food Science|language=en|volume=81|issue=4|pages=C867–C873|doi=10.1111/1750-3841.13257|issn=1750-3841}}</ref> Similar techniques are also used to analyze the interesting scents of locations and environments such as tea shops and saw mills. After the data is analyzed, the scents can then be recreated by a [[perfumer]].
One of the early pioneers of this technology includes [[Roman Kaiser]] who used it to measure and characterize the scents of tropical rainforest. <ref>{{citation |first=Roman |last=Kaiser |title=Environmental Scents at the Ligurian Coast |journal=Perfumer & Flavorist |year=1997 |volume=22 |pages=7–18}}</ref> Headspace techniques have since been used extensively to sample [[in vivo]] floral headspace of a large variety of numerous taxa and their aromatic compounds such as [[fatty acid]] derivatives ([[aldehyde]]s, [[alcohol]]s and [[ketone]]s), [[benzenoid]]s and [[isoprenoids]].<ref>{{citation |first=Jette T. |last=Knudsen|first2=Lars |last2=Tollsten|first3=L.Gunnar |last3=Bergström |title=Floral scents—a checklist of volatile compounds isolated by head-space techniques |journal=Phytochemistry |year=1993 |volume=33 |number=2 |pages=253–280 |doi=10.1016/0031-9422(93)85502-i}}</ref>
==Equipment== The headspace equipment involves a hollow dome or sphere-like objects which forms an airtight seal and surrounds the objects of interest. Inert gases are passed into the space containing the object or a vacuum is established such that the odor compounds are removed from the headspace.<ref name=Jenner>{{cite book | title = The Chemistry of Fragrances | first = Sell| last = Charles (Ed.) |author2=Karen Jenner| chapter = Chapter 14. The Search for Fragrance Ingredients| pages = 254–293 |publisher = Royal Society of Chemistry Publishing | isbn = 978-0-85404-824-3 | year = 2005| edition=2nd}}</ref> These compounds are in turn captured using a variety of techniques, among them cold surfaces, solvent traps, and adsorbent materials, with the latter techniques capable of longer periods of collection. The samples can then be analyzed using techniques such as [[gas chromatography]], [[mass spectrometry]], or Carbon-13 [[Nuclear magnetic resonance|NMR]].<ref name=Clery>{{cite book | title = The Chemistry of Fragrances | first = Sell| last = Charles (Ed.) |author2=Robin Clery | chapter = Chapter 12. Natural Product Analysis in the Fragrance Industry| pages = 214–228 |publisher = Royal Society of Chemistry Publishing | isbn = 978-0-85404-824-3 | year = 2005| edition=2nd}}</ref>
Several companies have patented similar headspace technologies: *Aromascope ([[Takasago International Corporation|Takasago]]) *Jungle Essence ([[Mane SA|Mane]]) *NaturePrint ([[Firmenich]]) *ScentTrek ([[Givaudan]])
